pull.title: util: improves error messages on get_previous_releases script
pull.body:
When previous releases are fetched and the specified version wasn't added to the checksum list we used to get a "Checksum did not match" which isn't true (https://github.com/bitcoin-core/bitcoincore.org/issues/753#issuecomment-879546719). 

If the specified version number is not on the list, it now logs cannot do the comparison instead.

issue.title: Downloads proceed rapidly, then stall
issue.body:
On downloading 0.21 from https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-0.21.0/ I observed the following behavior: the download would proceed rapidly for the first N mbs, then stall in a pending state without progress.

If I cancelled the download, then restarted it, it would continue rapidly from where it had left off. A few iterations of this were necessary to download.

This was via Chrome on macOS.

issue.title: test: Add feature_taproot.py --previous_release
issue.body: Disabling the new consensus code at runtime is fine, but potentially fragile and incomplete. Fix that by giving the option to run with a version that has been compiled without any taproot code.

events.body: Concept ACK with an error message comment.

Left two possible improvements that came up while reviewing the code. Couldn't test yet (the machine I am using right now is running OpenBSD, where the script doesn't work; even if the platform is overrided to e.g. 'x86_64-linux-gnu', the tar command fails), but will do tomorrow on a Linux machine.

> even if the platform is overrided to e.g. 'x86_64-linux-gnu', the tar command fails),

That sounds like something we should be able to fixup.

verification.payload:
tree a94de099a53985fdf2bdf40b6b15dd725877bf8e
parent d8f1e1327f9c2f9fcc804468f6a981580acdf30a
author Nelson Galdeman <nelsongaldeman@gmail.com> 1626771054 +0100
committer Nelson Galdeman <nelsongaldeman@gmail.com> 1626771054 +0100

util: improves error messages on get_previous_releases script

If a requested version doesn't exist on our list of checksums it says it cannot do a checksum comparision instead of saying it did not match

events.message:
util: improves error messages on get_previous_releases script

If a requested version doesn't exist on our list of checksums it says it cannot do a checksum comparision instead of saying it did not match

events.body:
tACK 179a051704321ba40277a5855d6ac0dbb45689dd, tested on Debian bullseye/sid

master branch:
```
$ ./test/get_previous_releases.py -b v0.21.0
Releases directory: releases
Fetching: https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-0.21.0/bitcoin-0.21.0-x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz
[ ... ]
Checksum did not match
$ echo $?
1
```
PR branch:
```
$ ./test/get_previous_releases.py -b v0.21.0
Releases directory: releases
Fetching: https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-0.21.0/bitcoin-0.21.0-x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz
[ ... ]
Checksum for given version doesn't exist
$ echo $?
1
```

By the way, welcome as a new contributor NelsonGaldeman! ðŸŽ‰ 

> > even if the platform is overrided to e.g. 'x86_64-linux-gnu', the tar command fails),
> 
> That sounds like something we should be able to fixup.

Yes, will take a look into that.

cr ACK 179a051704321ba40277a5855d6ac0dbb45689dd

Warm welcome as a new contributor @NelsonGaldeman! ðŸ¥‡

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -104,7 +104,12 @@ def download_binary(tag, args) -> int:
     tarballHash = hasher.hexdigest()
 
     if tarballHash not in SHA256_SUMS or SHA256_SUMS[tarballHash] != tarball:
-        print("Checksum did not match")
+        if sum_exists(tag[1:]):
+            print("Checksum did not match")
+            return 1
+
+        print("Cannot compare checksum for version {version}".format(
comments.body:
To me it seems like the new message isn't explaining the failure reason clearly.

Maybe a "Checksum for given version doesn't exist" or something like that could help more?

comments.body: Agree, my wording wasn't the best! Thank you for the suggestion. Updated.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -119,6 +123,13 @@ def download_binary(tag, args) -> int:
     return 0
 
 
+def checksum_exists(version) -> bool:
+    for sum in SHA256_SUMS:
+        if "bitcoin-" + version in SHA256_SUMS[sum]:
+            return True
+    return False
comments.body:
I think this could be simplified to a one-liner (maybe it could directly be used above then instead of introducing an extra function):
```suggestion
    return "bitcoin-" + version in SHA256_SUMS.values()
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -104,7 +104,11 @@ def download_binary(tag, args) -> int:
     tarballHash = hasher.hexdigest()
 
     if tarballHash not in SHA256_SUMS or SHA256_SUMS[tarballHash] != tarball:
-        print("Checksum did not match")
+        if checksum_exists(tag[1:]):
comments.body: nit: could also pass the full filename (`tarball`) here, then the function `checksum_exists` below wouldn't need to add the "bitcoin-" prefix and is more specific?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -119,6 +123,13 @@ def download_binary(tag, args) -> int:
     return 0
 
 
+def checksum_exists(version) -> bool:
+    for sum in SHA256_SUMS:
+        if "bitcoin-" + version in SHA256_SUMS[sum]:
+            return True
+    return False
comments.body:
Looking a second time at it, that was too simple-thought; it should be more like
```
    return any("bitcoin-" + version in str for str in SHA256_SUMS.values())
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -104,7 +104,11 @@ def download_binary(tag, args) -> int:
     tarballHash = hasher.hexdigest()
 
     if tarballHash not in SHA256_SUMS or SHA256_SUMS[tarballHash] != tarball:
-        print("Checksum did not match")
+        if checksum_exists(tag[1:]):
comments.body: I purposely avoided passing the full name in case the naming convention changes it will still work. Thinking more about it would be helpful to check the full name as it will throw the checksum doesn't exist if we are missing a specific OS/arch on the list even if we included some for that same version.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -119,6 +123,13 @@ def download_binary(tag, args) -> int:
     return 0
 
 
+def checksum_exists(version) -> bool:
+    for sum in SHA256_SUMS:
+        if "bitcoin-" + version in SHA256_SUMS[sum]:
+            return True
+    return False
comments.body: Yes absolutely! My python is a little bit rusty it's been a while. I didn't know I could do that, it looks cleaner. Thank you!
